original_table_html:
Competitor Brand Features
Coca-Cola Vitaminwater Regular and zero-calorie versions; 18 varieties; each flavor provides a different function based on blend of vitamins and minerals; vapor distilled, de-ionized, and/or filtered; sweetened with crystalline fructose and cane sugar; 20-ounce single-serve or multipack, fountain, and drops.
PepsiCo Propel Zero-calorie only; 10 flavors; fitness positioning based on “Replenish + Energize + Protect”; B vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, antioxidants, and electrolytes; sweetened with sucralose; 16.9-ounce, 20-ounce PET bottles and multipacks; powdered packets; liquid enhancer.
PepsiCo SoBe Lifewater Six zero-calorie versions; vitamins, minerals, and herbs; Pure—mildly flavored, sweetened with Stevia; “all natural”; 20-ounce single-serve and multipacks.
summary_markdown: This table presents a comparative analysis of three enhanced water brands, highlighting their features and positioning within the beverage market. Coca-Cola's Vitaminwater offers a broad range with regular and zero-calorie options across 18 varieties, each emphasizing specific functional benefits through vitamin and mineral blends, and available in various formats. PepsiCo's Propel focuses exclusively on zero-calorie, fitness-oriented hydration, featuring B vitamins, vitamins C and E, antioxidants, and electrolytes, sweetened with sucralose, and offered in multiple product forms including powdered packets and liquid enhancers. PepsiCo's SoBe Lifewater provides six zero-calorie versions, emphasizing "all natural" ingredients with vitamins, minerals, herbs, and Stevia as a sweetener, available in single-serve and multipack bottles. The structure is comparative, detailing product differentiation across key attributes like calorie content, flavor variety, functional claims, ingredients, and packaging.
